title: How many Roman soldiers were in a legion? - Quora

response.answer_text: That depends very much on the tie period. Often a figure of about 4,200 men is given, but this is only a nominal value, which often wasn’t even reached on paper. In practive, as with modenr military, legions tended to be under nominal strength. Secondly, it very much depends on the type of legion. Consular legions could be bigger, praetorian legions tended to be saller, as they weren’t actually combat units. Here’s a short survey: Legion: alphabetically This looks more reliable than wikepedia’s article on Roman legions, as it assumes a single unchanging number of men, whcih is demonstrably false.

5,000 Citizen soldiers (Legionnaires) About 1000 Non Citizen Soldiers (Auxiliaries) Auxiliaries did things the Legionnaires didn’t, while the Legionnaires were mostly heavy infantry. Auxiliaries were cavalry, archers, slingers, cooks etc etc etc
